values: Applied by game logic based on weapon tags, not in formula
Attack speed in attacks per second. Higher = faster attacks. Handedness (1H/2H) affects speed via game logic based on tags.
Chestplate provides most defense (1.5x), extremities provide less (0.6-0.8x)
Use to make specific items special (1.0 = baseline, 1.5 = 50% better, 0.5 = 50% lighter/weaker)
Mithril = lightweight (0.5x weight), Adamantine = indestructible (2.0x durability)
Each tier should be roughly 2x stronger than previous tier (via tierMultiplier)
Tools at 60% weapon damage ensures they're viable but not optimal for combat
Different weapon types trade damage for speed or reach
Heavy armor = more defense but slower movement, light armor = mobility
Consumables use tier-based effect scaling rather than formulas
Tools and shields can be used in combat but deal reduced damage
globalBases.weaponDamage × tierMultiplier × categoryMultiplier × typeMultiplier × subtypeMultiplier × itemMultiplier
Final damage is randomized within this range
Shields provide defense through blocking mechanic, not defense stat
Devices scale by tier and material rarity used in recipe
Item functions infinitely at 50% effectiveness (never breaks completely)
Drastically increases durability drain (pickaxe in combat, sword for mining)
Accessories use durability: 0 to indicate infinite durability (never breaks)
Gathering stat determines harvest speed and yield
Range is NOT formula-based, defined per weapon type as flat values in items
Rarity affects drop rates and visual style, NOT stats directly. Stats controlled by item multipliers and materials used.
Excellent materials or excellent mini-game performance
Quality materials or good mini-game performance
One-of-a-kind, special quest rewards or discoveries
Mithril Greatsword with itemMultiplier 0.5 would be: 4.0 (T3) × 1.6 × 0.5 = 3.2 kg (same weight as T2 steel!)
globalBases.weight × tierMultiplier × categoryMultiplier × typeMultiplier × subtypeMultiplier × itemMultiplier
Weight affects inventory capacity and possibly movement speed. Mithril items can have itemMultiplier < 1.0 to be lighter.

handednessModifiers.note: Applied by game logic based on weapon tags, not in formula

attackSpeedSystem.note: Attack speed in attacks per second. Higher = faster attacks. Handedness (1H/2H) affects speed via game logic based on tags.

balancingGuidelines.armorSlots: Chestplate provides most defense (1.5x), extremities provide less (0.6-0.8x)
balancingGuidelines.itemMultipliers: Use to make specific items special (1.0 = baseline, 1.5 = 50% better, 0.5 = 50% lighter/weaker)
balancingGuidelines.legendaryMaterials: Mithril = lightweight (0.5x weight), Adamantine = indestructible (2.0x durability)
balancingGuidelines.tierProgression: Each tier should be roughly 2x stronger than previous tier (via tierMultiplier)
balancingGuidelines.toolCombat: Tools at 60% weapon damage ensures they're viable but not optimal for combat
balancingGuidelines.weaponVariety: Different weapon types trade damage for speed or reach
balancingGuidelines.weightTradeoffs: Heavy armor = more defense but slower movement, light armor = mobility

consumableSystem.note: Consumables use tier-based effect scaling rather than formulas

categoryMultipliers.note: Tools and shields can be used in combat but deal reduced damage

damageSystem.formula: globalBases.weaponDamage × tierMultiplier × categoryMultiplier × typeMultiplier × subtypeMultiplier × itemMultiplier

varianceRange.note: Final damage is randomized within this range

defenseSystem.note: Shields provide defense through blocking mechanic, not defense stat

deviceSystem.note: Devices scale by tier and material rarity used in recipe

durabilityMechanics.at_0_percent: Item functions infinitely at 50% effectiveness (never breaks completely)
durabilityMechanics.wrongToolUsage: Drastically increases durability drain (pickaxe in combat, sword for mining)

durabilitySystem.note: Accessories use durability: 0 to indicate infinite durability (never breaks)

gatheringSystem.note: Gathering stat determines harvest speed and yield

rangeSystem.note: Range is NOT formula-based, defined per weapon type as flat values in items

raritySystem.note: Rarity affects drop rates and visual style, NOT stats directly. Stats controlled by item multipliers and materials used.

rarityTiers.rare: Excellent materials or excellent mini-game performance
rarityTiers.uncommon: Quality materials or good mini-game performance
rarityTiers.unique: One-of-a-kind, special quest rewards or discoveries
